javadoc:
An object that maps vertices to rows and columns and edges to their articulation points. This class is essentially a container that allows layout algorithms to store results, which can later be turned into layout positioning points. The integer point values in this class are row, column grid values, starting at 0,0.

Note: the Point2D values for the edge articulations use x,y values that are row and column index values, the same values as calling {@link #row(V)} and {@link #col(V)}.

After building the grid using this class, clients can call {@link #rows()} to get high-order object that represent rows. @param the vertex type @param the edge type

methods.javadoc:
Returns the rows in this grid, sorted by index (index can be negative)
@return the rows in this grid
methods.name: rows
methods.comment: Returns the rows in this grid, sorted by index (index can be negative)

methods.javadoc:
Updates each row within the grid such that it's x values are set to center the row in
 the grid.  Each row will be updated so that all its columns start at zero.  After that, 
 each column will be centered in the grid.
methods.name: centerRows
methods.comment:
Updates each row within the grid such that it's x values are set to center the row in
 the grid.  Each row will be updated so that all its columns start at zero.  After that, 
 each column will be centered in the grid.

methods.javadoc:
Creates a string representation of this grid
@return a string representation of this grid
methods.name: toStringGrid
methods.comment: Creates a string representation of this grid

return.comment: a string representation of this grid

name: GridLocationMap
comment:
An object that maps vertices to rows and columns and edges to their articulation points.  
 This class is essentially a container that allows layout algorithms to store results, which
 can later be turned into layout positioning points.   The integer point values in this 
 class are row, column grid values, starting at 0,0.
 
 Note: the Point2D values for the edge articulations use x,y values that are row and 
 column index values, the same values as calling #row(V) and #col(V).

 After building the grid using this class, clients can call #rows() to get 
 high-order object that represent rows.
